I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) for Strengthening Carbon 
Financing for Regional Grassland Management in Northeast Asia1 is a continuation of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) support for regional cooperation among the countries of Northeast 
Asia to combat dust and sandstorms. The TA will contribute to the implementation of the 
regional master plan that was prepared under TA on Prevention and Control of Dust and 
Sandstorms  in  Northeast  Asia.2  In  January  and  February  2010,  ADB  missions  visited  the 
People's  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  Mongolia,  and  reached  an  understanding  with  the 
governments  on  the  TA’s  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  cost  estimates,  financing  plan, 
implementation arrangements, and consultants’ terms of reference.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Dust and sandstorms are the end products of desertification, which has become a 
regional  environmental  (ecosystem  degradation)  problem  in  grasslands  in  Northeast  Asia.3 
Grasslands constitute about 40% of land area in the PRC and 80% in Mongolia. Inappropriate 
grassland management practices and development policies have led to degradation and the 
breakdown of traditional resource management systems. Conversion to cultivated crops and 
overgrazing through changes in the number, type, and movement of livestock have reduced 
land cover, biodiversity, and soil fertility. Moreover, grasslands are vulnerable to the impacts of 
climate change, including more frequent droughts, and shortage of water and forage.  
 
3.  Ecosystem degradation has caused a steady increase in the annual number of dust and 
sandstorms in Northeast Asia. The environmental, economic, and social consequences for the 
rural population in Northeast Asia are serious and include the destruction of farmland; loss of 
livestock;  and  damage  to  houses,  settlements,  and  community  infrastructure.  Dust  and 
sandstorms have also disrupted power supplies, telecommunications, and transport services, 
while poor air quality has led to more health problems. The same events have also reduced air 
quality in Japan and the Korean Peninsula, and dust particles originating from the PRC and 
Mongolia have reached as far as the west coast of North America. 
 
4.  Over the last 20 years, the PRC and Mongolia have developed new environmental 
policies and implemented investment programs to address the problems of land degradation. 
Recognizing that dust and sandstorms have regional impacts, the governments of the PRC and 
Mongolia collaborated in the development of a regional master plan for the prevention and 
control of such events in Northeast Asia.4 The master plan was developed in association with 
Japan and the Republic of Korea, and supported by ADB, the United Nations Environment 
Programme, the United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Asia and the Pacific, and 
the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification Secretariat. 
 
5.  Improvement of grassland management practices and the development of sustainable 
financing mechanisms are among the key actions proposed in the regional master plan. While 
there are many studies and programs to improve grassland management practices, to date 
there are only few projects that (i) monitor soil carbon sequestration, (ii) demonstrate the value

communities in adapting to climate impacts. Recent research shows that more sustainable 
management practices can significantly increase carbon stocks in the degraded grasslands.5 
Reported  carbon  sequestration  potential  for  grassland  management  practices  includes 
vegetation  cultivation  (9.39  tons  [t]  of  carbon  dioxide  equivalent  per  hectare  per  year 
[CO e/ha/year]),  land-use  change  (0.40t  CO e/ha/year),  grazing  management  (2.16t

6.  The TA is in line with ADB’s core area of operations under Strategy 20207 and its 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Strategy (2006).8 It is also in line with the efforts of the 
PRC  and  Mongolia  to  strengthen  sustainable  development  and  reverse  environmental 
degradation at the national levels.9   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The TA will help reduce the occurrence of dust and sandstorms in Northeast Asia. It will 
help reduce infrastructure damage and public health issues resulting from these events for 
millions of people, particularly the poor, in the participating countries. Specifically, the TA will 
strengthen the capacity of the governments of the PRC and Mongolia to support communities in 
accessing carbon financing by applying sustainable grassland management practices. It will 
provide  the  necessary  methodologies,  tools,  and  studies  to  introduce  sustainable  carbon 
financing  mechanisms  for  grassland  management  projects  in  the  PRC  and  Mongolia.  The 
design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will deliver the following outputs:  
 
(i)  Review of financing mechanisms for sustainable grassland management. A 
study on financing sustainable grassland management will (a) review the current 
policy and regulatory framework for grassland management in Northeast Asia, 
(b) estimate the economic value of the grasslands, (c) identify the link between 
conditions of grasslands and occurrence of dust and sandstorms, (d) review 
regional data-monitoring and information-sharing arrangements regarding land 
degradation  and  carbon  stocks,  and  (e)  prepare  recommendations  on 
opportunities to access international and local carbon markets. The findings of 
the study will be discussed and disseminated through a regional workshop, and 
through  the  publication  of  a  report  on  potential  financing  mechanisms  for

sustainable  grassland  management.  A  study  tour  will  be  conducted  to  gain 
practical experience from similar initiatives outside of Northeast Asia.  
 
(ii)  Field assessments on carbon sequestration potential and monitoring of 
grasslands. Selected field studies will be conducted to determine and confirm 
the potential for carbon sequestration in grasslands, such as (a) establish soil 
carbon  baselines  at  eight  demonstration  sites;  (b)  establish  quantitative 
estimates  of  carbon  sinks,  according  to  representative  types  and  state  of 
degraded grasslands; (c) develop methodological guidelines for assessing and 
monitoring soil carbon, including establishing a practical approach to extrapolate 
field sampling data;10 (d) design a network to monitor carbon sequestration, and 
dust  and  sandstorms  at  the  demonstration  sites;  and  (e)  determine 
methodologies for establishing baselines, measuring, and monitoring, reporting, 
and verifying sequestered CO . Building on the initial achievement of ADB TA on 
2
Prevention and Control of Dust and Sandstorms in Northeast Asia (footnote 2), 
the TA will also further enhance regional cooperation on monitoring and data 
sharing, and establish cooperation mechanisms to supplement ongoing regional 
and national initiatives for soil carbon and land degradation monitoring. The 
findings of the study will be discussed and disseminated through a regional 
workshop, and the publication of a final report on carbon sequestration potential 
and monitoring of grasslands in Northeast Asia. 
 
(iii)  Heightened awareness of carbon financing opportunities for sustainable 
grassland  management.  The  TA  will  support  the  local  communities  and 
governments  at  the  eight  demonstration  sites  in  determining  and  adopting 
grassland management practices that may be eligible for carbon financing. The 
TA will (a) review international experiences with payment for ecological services 
and land tenure, including in Northeast Asia; (b) consult beneficiaries at the eight 
demonstration sites to identify opportunities for carbon financing through better 
grassland management practices; (c) assess opportunities for and barriers to 
community participation in accessing voluntary carbon markets (adaptation and 
mitigation); (d) identify institutional arrangements to maximize ownership by the 
beneficiaries  of  the  potential  projects;  (e)  draft  methodologies  for  preparing 
community agreements for accessing carbon financing through voluntary carbon 
markets; and (f) prepare training materials to raise awareness of the grassland 
sequestration  potential.  The  findings  of  the  study  will  be  discussed  and 
disseminated through a regional workshop, and the publication of a final report 
on the approaches to community participation in voluntary carbon markets for 
more sustainable grassland management in Northeast Asia. 
 
(iv)  Development  of  terrestrial  carbon  financing  opportunities  for  Northeast 
Asia. Based on the field assessment and the identified potential for soil carbon 
sequestration, the TA will support the governments of the PRC and Mongolia in 
formulating project proposals that will be eligible for financing through possible 
post-201211  adaptation  or  mitigation  carbon  markets  or  funds.  The  activities 
include  (a)  reviewing  possible  post-2012  regional  and  international  carbon

market  mechanisms;  (b)  assessing  opportunities  for  carbon  financing  for 
grassland sequestration, particularly among the voluntary carbon markets (e.g., 
the Chicago Carbon Exchange or regional voluntary markets); (c) preparing at 
least two project proposals for carbon financing; and (d) initiating discussions 
with  the  potential  financiers.  A  regional  workshop  will  be  organized  to 
disseminate the final TA report. 
 
(v)  Project management and support. The TA will provide overall support for the 
implementation of the project activities specified for each component, and ensure 
that project outcomes and outputs are delivered on time and with the expected 
quality. The outputs will include all project-related reports and workshops.  
 
9.  Eight demonstration sites12 were identified during the implementation of ADB TA on 
Prevention and Control of Dust and Sandstorms in Northeast Asia (footnote 2). The sites, all 
source  areas  of  dust  and  sandstorms,  were  selected  because  they  represent  different 
ecosystems with an array of land uses, population densities, and poor ecological conditions. 
Further details on the feasibility of working in these demonstration sites will be discussed with 
the consultants and national experts during the inception phase. The key considerations will be 
(i) the potential of the degraded grasslands to sequester carbon, and (ii) the capacity for low-
cost soil carbon measurements that will establish reliable baseline conditions. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The  TA  is  estimated  to  cost  $1,800,000  equivalent.  ADB  will  provide  $1,000,000 
equivalent on a grant basis from the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund under the 
Regional Cooperation and Integration Financing Partnership Facility and $400,000 equivalent 
on  a  grant  basis  from  the  People's  Republic  of  China  Regional  Cooperation  and  Poverty 
Reduction  Fund,  administered  by  ADB.13  The  governments  of  the  PRC  and  Mongolia  will 
finance the remaining $400,000 equivalent in kind to cover counterpart costs and services 
including  office  accommodation,  data  processing  and  preparation,  and  remuneration  of 
counterpart staff. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
11.  The TA will be implemented from July 2010 to June 2012. ADB will be the executing 
agency  for  the  TA.  In  the  PRC,  the  implementing  agency  will  be  the  Foreign  Economic 
Cooperation Center of the Ministry of Agriculture. Guided by the ministry’s Department for 
International Cooperation, the Foreign Economic Cooperation Center will closely cooperate with 
the PRC's Center of Grassland Supervision and Monitoring. A national technical working group 
will be established with representatives from the Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Agriculture, 
the State Forestry Administration, and the Ministry of Environmental Protection. In Mongolia, the 
Department of International Cooperation of the Ministry of Nature, Environment, and Tourism 
will be the implementing agency. A national technical working group will involve experts from the 
Department of International Cooperation of the Ministry of Food, Agriculture, and Light Industry; 
                                                 
12 These consist of four sites in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region in the PRC (Alashan, Hulunbuir, Ordos 
Plateau, and Xilingol) and four sites in the southern part of Mongolia (Dornogobi, Omnogobi, Ovorhangai, and 
Sukhbaatar). 
13  Partial funding was secured from the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty Reduction 
Fund in 2005. Proposed cofinancing from the GEF never materialized. A revised scope of the TA suitable for 
financing by the Regional Cooperation and Integration Fund was prepared in consultation with the governments of 
the PRC and Mongolia.

5
the Ministry of Finance; the National Agency for Meteorology and Environment Monitoring; and 
the National Committee for Climate Change.  
 
12.  Both national working groups will ensure close coordination and cooperation with the 
national focal points for the United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification, the United 
Nations  Framework  Convention  on  Climate  Change,  and  other  relevant  stakeholders.  The 
national focal points will be invited to join the national technical working groups, and discussions 
will be held among the stakeholders on efficient information and data-sharing arrangements, 
both  nationally  and  regionally.  Notably,  the  ongoing  programs  of  the  National  Agency  for 
Meteorology  and  Environment  Monitoring  in  Mongolia  and  the  Ministry  of  Environmental 
Protection in the PRC will contribute to the work at the demonstration sites.  
 
13.  A team of individual consultants will be recruited for a total of 114 person-months, 
comprising three international experts for 18 person-months and eight national experts for 96 
person-months.  ADB  will  engage  the  consultants  using  the  individual  selection  method  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). Individual consultant engagements are considered as more efficient for the TA as they will 
allow quality control in the selection and management of the national experts, and consultants 
can  be  mobilized  more  rapidly.  The  outline  terms  of  reference  of  the  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. The international consultants will distribute their inputs equally between the PRC 
and Mongolia to work directly with the respective implementing agencies. The implementing 
agencies will handle the procurement of equipment under the TA in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). Ownership of the equipment will 
be transferred to the implementing agencies upon TA completion. Disbursement under the TA 
will be done in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook.14 
 
14.  Implementation progress will be monitored through (i) inception, interim, and final TA 
review missions; (ii) regional workshops; and (iii) TA reports and technical publications. The 
schedule for the regional workshops and TA reports is in the design and monitoring framework. 
The main reports will be prepared in Chinese, English, and Mongolian languages. The findings 
will be disseminated through workshops, conferences, and a TA website. The outputs of the TA 
will also be made available on websites of ADB and the implementing agencies.  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
15.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the People's Republic of China Regional Cooperation and Poverty 
Reduction Fund; and (ii) ADB providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 
on a grant basis for Strengthening Carbon Financing for Regional Grassland Management in 
Northeast Asia, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

comprising three international and eight national experts. The consultants will be engaged by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) using the individual selection method in accordance with 
ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Individual 
engagements are considered to be most economical and efficient for the regional capacity 
development technical assistance (TA). The table below summarizes the estimated international 
and national consultant inputs required.

B.  Terms of Reference
